displayed_text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, and is that just a swollen gland from inflammation that’s coming there. Cancer really shouldn’t give you a gland. You know, unless that gland is involved. Um, but that’s where the normal prostate cancer goes. It goes to the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, I can’t, I’m not judging. I don’t know what that is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Your CAT scan, uh, says that there’s more, uh, there’s more scarring at the bone sites. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, that’s why they can see scarring on CAT scans, but that’s just again, inflammation. Um. And they love to use . And then, the only change that we see is in your right adrenal gland. Patient: MM, hmm. Doctor: And they’re saying there’s a nodular appearance, and there’s inflammation around it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so, they don’t know what it is. I went up there. That’s why I wasn’t in right when you got here ‘cuz I wanted to go over it with the radiologist. Like, can you tell me what you think it is, and they don’t know. They’re hedging. Okay? Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s that simple. I mean when you look across all the thousands of guys with prostate cancer and all the different things out there, the bottom line is don’t get fat. Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: And how will you do that? It doesn’t matter. It’s the fact that you don’t. Patient: Right. Family Member: And now I have a question, and you can tell me if you know how to answer this but you know you’re saying here you’re giving us all our options. Is your heart in one place and the other with standard of care two versus the chemo and super hormone for somebody like him? Doctor: Sure. I’m a too. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I’m an ah aggressive guy. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Um you’re a young guy. You don’t want to look back. Or if it was me, Family Member: Um hum.

Patient: What kind of breathing machine? Doctor: Uh. A ventilator. On TV. Those are television. Your body’s gotten so sick that if I get you to wake up, you still have the bad cancer. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Okay? So, I also, I mean, I’m not so sure we should be pounding on your chest. Uh, you should be thinking about how far will we go even if it looks bad. (Pause) Patient: No. See, my dad died from prostate cancer in nineteen eighty six. He hadn’t -- didn’t have much treatment at all. Uh. Family Member: He waited, he waited to have severe symptoms. Then he went and then (they’s found) Patient: So, um, you know, I’m concerned for my son. My brother. Uh. He might have something too. I mean, if I try somethin’, it will help ‘em. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, so this may not help you, but it may help us learn how to treat other men in the future. Uh. So, that is, you know, just you being a good citizen and helping that out and a hero, but that – you have to feel comfortable with that, you know, ‘cuz it could help. It may not help. If it does help, it may help others. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. And yet it’s your time. It’s your coming in here. Some of it’s your expense. You know, this drug enzalutamide, I don’t know what you were paying when you were on it before. Uh. It’s pretty expensive. It’s about ten thousand bucks a month. Um. And again, you would be taking it, even though we don’t think it’s gonna work ‘cuz -- because we think that it may make the immune therapy work better. So, we have to have people on it. Their PSA’s gonna be rising. Their ARV seven still has to be positive. (Laughs) Patient: Okay. I didn’t pay much for the Xtandi before. Uh, some kind of study from manufacturers – Doctor: Oh, so you had a study, or they had a, uh, a program that sort of reduced your cost?

Patient: Don’t go there. I’m trying to ask a good question – Doctor: Okay. Patient: - that I’m trying to feel and understand and I know you have an answer as to if that’s going down, why am I feeling this pain again? Has the chemo kind of lessened up again that’s why we need a second and a third one to really go after them? Doctor: Yeah. Well it’s not lessened up, it’s just this does not do anything. This is a nice false sense of like hmm it’s going in the right direction. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you have plenty more cells we got to kill. Patient: Yeah, yeah, okay. Doctor: So that’s one. Normally it takes three to sometimes four doses… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …for it to work and that’s true for most medicines. It takes three to four doses of anything for anything to work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You don’t have enough in your blood stream to do anything.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So stopping with the clinical trial therapy and preceding with non-hormonal therapy. time to try something else. Patient: And that would be the … Doctor: That would be the example. Patient: Okay. Can you tell me my Gleason score? Doctor: Your Gleason score was a seven out of ten and that was based on your in two thousand and seven. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If patients are a Gleason score of eight or more, high risk of progression. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If it’s a Gleason score of seven I would consider that and intermediate risk and a Gleason score of seven Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Two ways of having a Gleason score of seven. Three plus four is seven or equals seven. Those two um numbers are different depending Gleason if

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.Yes, Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::Yes, Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: It paralyzes or something. I don’t like that feeling. Doctor: Yeah. No, I don’t want to wait until you get paralyzed either. Patient: It would be in my arms. Doctor: Right. Patient: It would be in my arms and my feet, my toes. Doctor: Yeah, because, but we don’t want to wait until you know it totally messes up with your… Doctor: …walking and stuff. Patient: It’s coming a long… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but the cancer has stayed in check for a really long time with the chemo… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …so I think uh so far the chemo has done you good. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Alright. So today we’ll go ahead and I know you gave G____ the list of medications…

Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: What is it? Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: Do you have any- Doctor: That is like, I’m going to shoot you. I’ll be right back. Okay boss. Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: You had to scare me like that. I have no idea. Family Member: I just gave him some M and M’s. Good thing I brought them in. Not M and M’s but Good and Plenty. Doctor: Why you running so low? Family Member: He ate breakfast but he didn’t eat it all at the restaurant. Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: He had an omelet and toast and .

Patient: Right. So I get twelve and twelve; I’ll take it at twelve and then I’ll take it again at twelve midnight. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: When I’m laying down and going to sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And this is… Doctor: This is the sleeping pill, the Restoril. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright and these are your blood tests which you take over. Your calcium is good now so you can get… Patient: My calcium is good and I don’t have to take the big bills? Doctor: So it sounds like the big pills, you’re doing what I told you to. Doctor: Oh God.

Family Member: Yeah. Yeah. They were dealing with somebody that was off, a robber or something. Patient: Okay. Well that didn’t affect our drive. Doctor: No. But I’m sure with the game. Never, never rush. Don’t stress. You know? It’s not great for your sugar and then you’re on the XTANDI. Family Member: You were only fifteen minutes late so it’s fine. Patient: Yeah. And the other issue was this (laugh) Patient: We weren’t aware what we were doing. Family Member: Yeah you were. We had an appointment with this guy Come in at eleven thirty. Right. Doctor: It’s all your fault his sugar is low, not back and forth. (Laughs) Patient: No. He said no (Laughter) Doctor: You feeling better? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So, let me see if you want. Do you want to do it today? Patient: I mean Doctor: You can go over and do it. Patient: What? Doctor: To the treatment area. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You have an appointment there anyway. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay?
